body: There's still one potential issue with this approach. If someone sets anything in the `workUnitstate` that is supposed to overwrite the static config in the method `Source.getExtractor(WorkUnitState workUnitstate)`, the changes will be lost when `JobState` gets added back.

I think this may also require changes to `AbstractSource`. The method `getPreviousWorkUnitStatesForRetry` contains some code to use a config `ConfigurationKeys.OVERWRITE_CONFIGS_IN_STATESTORE`. If this config is set to true then all properties in the specified `SourceState` object are added to each `WorkUnitState`. I'm guessing this is something we would want to change too.
@zliu41 Can you review? I'm not 100% sure about the new location of the Limiter classes that had to be moved so let me know if they're incorrect

LGTM

It looks like the goal of `getPreviousSourceState` is to return a `SourceState` that cannot be modified, which I think is the correct approach. However, `getPreviousWorkUnitStates` only returns an `ImmutableList` of `WorkUnitState`s. While the list itself cannot be modified there is nothing stopping a user from modifying the `WorkUnitState`s inside the list. Perhaps we should consider creating an `ImmutableState` class, or just migrating to something like commons-configuration which already provides these types of things.
Good point, I will create an `ImmutableWorkUnitState` class.
If every `SourceState` also contains a copy of the previous `SourceState`, then will the size of `SourceState` grow infinitely?
No. Note that `previousSourceState` is not persisted. So when the previous `SourceState` is read from the state store, it does not contain the `SourceState` of the run before the previous run.
Updated to add a `ImmutableWorkUnitState` class and use it in `SourceState`.

I just realized that we can simply turn-on a per-mapper time limiter by setting the following properties
`extract.limit.enabled`
`extract.limit.type`
`extract.limit.time.limit`
`extract.limit.time.limit.timeunit`
So I'll see how well the per-mapper time limiter works. If it's more desirable to use a per-partition time limiter, then I'll revisit this PR.
LGTM. I am not sure if this is expected, but it is definitely not necessary.
@liyinan926 and @ydailinkedin can you take a look?

Interested observer here: The roadmap calls for ORC, Parquet and many other types of HDFS writers I presume. When would it make sense to abstract the file attribute setting code out from the file format code? Put another way, setting the permissions and group ownership is independent of Avro. At some point in the future, setting Hadoop ACLs to facilitate more advanced security needs being required, you would not want to couple that to Avro, vs. ORC vs. Parquet...
Respectfully,
Douglas
@dmoore247 yes, code that deals with general file attributes should be moved to `FsDataWriter`. We will fix this.

Since both these classes implement `Closeable` would it just be easier to shutdown the `ExecutorService` in the `close()` method. We could just use Guava's `MoreExecutors.shutdownAndAwaitTermination` method (http://docs.guava-libraries.googlecode.com/git-history/master/javadoc/com/google/common/util/concurrent/MoreExecutors.html#shutdownAndAwaitTermination(java.util.concurrent.ExecutorService,%20long,%20java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit))

While both approaches achieve the same thing, I think this is a little cleaner. It looks like `MoreExecutors. getExitingExecutorService` basically sets all the threads as daemon threads, and then adds a shutdown hook to cleanly shutdown all the daemon threads, which sounds a little like a hack.

Just a thought, I'm fine with either approach.

There are two issues with that approach:
- The main problem here is that `MoreExecutors.shutdownAndAwaitTermination` was introduced in version 17.0 of Guava, and we are using version 15.0. I tried upgrading the version, but we would have to also update all downstream projects, or risk breaking things.
- Also, if a user forgets to close a MetricContext, their program will hang, and it will probably take a while for them to find the root cause. With this implementation, the executors close themselves, with minimal input from user.

Ok, thats fine. Some other comments.
- It looks like we are on Guava 18.0
- Is it necessary for each `MetricContext` to have its own threadpool. I'm not that familiar with the metrics implementation, but my understanding is that each class you want to emit metrics from requires one to create a new `MetricContext`, which in turn requires the class to create a new thread pool. My guess is that this would add more overhead than necessary, since you could just have one, centralized `ExecutorService`.
The thread pool is created lazily. Only `MetricContext` that are reporting events create one (almost always only one `MetricContext`).
@ydailinkedin and @ibuenros could you both please review?
@liyinan926 please a take a look. Thanks.
Is it possible that each workunit has multiple datasets? Currently each Kafka workunit contains multiple partitions, each of which should be a dataset.

The problem with allowing a `WorkUnit` to have multiple dataset labels is there's no easy way to tell if each dataset in the `WorkUnit` has been successfully processed so there's no reliable way to determine if a dataset should be committed.
If multiple workunits have the same `dataset.urn`, then `JobContext.commit()` needs to check that all workunits of a urn succeeded before committing a dataset. Where is this check performed?
Take a look at `commitDataset` and `canCommitDataset` in `JobContext`.
